article.description: David Wesley and Baron Davis each scored 22 points as the Hornets remained unbeaten at New Orleans Arena with a 105-87 victory over the Chicago Bulls.
article.headline: Hornets win second half 56-35
article.linkText: Hornets roar away from Bulls with huge second half
article.story:
NEW ORLEANS (AP) -- The New Orleans Hornets claimed it was strong defense in the second half that made the difference.
Davis

Jalen Rose suspected an "X-rated'' halftime speech by New Orleans coach Paul Silas had something to do with it, too, as the Hornets defeated the Chicago Bulls 105-87 Friday night. After trailing 59-52 at the half, the Hornets held the Bulls to 4-of-17 shooting and outscored them 34-14 in the third quarter to take the lead for good. "We're all good individual defensive players and we're a good collective defensive unit,'' said Baron Davis, who led the Hornets with 22 points and 12 assists. "When we come out and stop teams from scoring that's how going to win and win big this year.'' David Wesley also scored 22 points, including three 3-pointers. "Everything with us pretty much starts with defense,'' Wesley said. "If we can get stops and get steals and get in passing lanes ... then we can get out on the break,'' Wesley said. "If we're always getting the ball under the basket then we can't run, and that's what happened in the first half.'' Rose led the Bulls with 23 but had trouble scoring in the second half. Rookie Lonny Baxter added 11 off the bench and Eddy Curry scored 10 for Chicago, which shot 12-of-36 over the last two periods. "I'm pretty sure Paul Silas went in there (at halftime) and had an X-rated speech for his team, and they came out and they beat us to the punch,'' Rose said. "Obviously we're a young team ... And I think once (New Orleans) got the lead we stopped competing and that's something we can't do.'' Jamal Mashburn added 16 points, while P.J. Brown had 12 points and 11 rebounds. Robert Traylor scored 10 for New Orleans and had three dunks, all in the fourth quarter as he got open under the basket by sneaking in from the weak side. After the Bulls scored the first basket of the third quarter, the Hornets turned a 54-49 deficit into a 83-66 lead. New Orleans forced eight third-quarter turnovers while hitting 12 of 20 field goals in the period. They scored 12 fast-break points in the second half after getting none through the first half. "I let them know at halftime that we did not have one fast break,'' Silas said. "We weren't moving the ball, we weren't hustling. When all those things fell into place, we blew them away.'' Bulls coach Bill Cartwright said he felt his club was prepared for the Hornets and wouldn't criticize his players' effort. "The guys played hard but we just made some silly turnovers and they got it going,'' he said. "Silliness really cost us and they took advantage of it.'' New Orleans was outshot 54 percent to 43 percent in the first half but was able to stay within 52-49 thanks to 6-for-11 3-point shooting, with Davis, Mashburn and Wesley each hitting two. Rose scored 18 in the first half for the Bulls, including a one-handed floater as he spun in the air after pulling up on a drive.

Game notes
The Hornets did not get their first field goal of the second quarter until there was 7:49 left in the period. The basket was Mashburn's first of the game. He sat out much of the first quarter after committing two early fouls. He leads the Hornets in scoring with 21.4 points per game. ... Wesley has hit a 3-pointer in all nine games this season. ... Curry eclipsed his 7.4 points-per-game average in the first quarter when he scored eight points, but he finished with only one more basket. ... Free-throw shooting was among the few bright spots for a Chicago team that had been struggling from the line at 63 percent. The Bulls hit 19 of 23, or 83 percent.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
